docs.lead_paragraph: FOR years I begged my family to observe Christmas on Dec. 28 so we could take advantage of the post-holiday markdowns. I argued that final-sale eggnog tasted just as sweet and we could even get some things free by then, if we had the gumption to salvage one of the Christmas trees the neighbors had dragged to the curb. Some still have tinsel. These were not merely the desperate ravings of a truly cheap person. O.K., they were. But you have to admit my plan also would be an effective way to avoid a certain kind of shopper's remorse, that hot scorch of shame you feel upon realizing that the same cashmere sweater for which you paid full price last week is now $1.25.

headline.main: Mourning the Magic Of Markdowns Past

docs.abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on shopping for post-Christmas bargains online; notes observation by Paco Underhill, consultant and author, that retailers have so overused markdown that they have destroyed its usefulness as marketing tool (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE court-ordered auction of the assets of Webvan was something of a spectator sport, Silicon Valley style. Dozens of former employees, reporters, television crews and gawkers, many of them unemployed technology workers, gathered in late October at the company's shuttered headquarters near San Francisco for a sell-off of computer and office equipment. It was as much a chance to witness the final chapter in one of the most spectacular failures of the Internet bubble as to gaze at piles of some of the most sophisticated technology gear anywhere.

docs.lead_paragraph: BOB SMITH'S office in a Hauppauge industrial park is a mecca for snakes, amphibians and bugs. There's Dumpy, a silky smooth, lime green Australian tree frog with a dreamy, smiley look on his face, sitting on the tray of Mr. Smith's business-card holder, breathing ever so gently that the nocturnal amphibian looks more like a gargoyle. Lurking under the moss in the terrarium by Mr. Smith's desk is a Brazilian rainbow boa constrictor that had 26 babies earlier this year, though the offspring have been relocated to separate lodgings in his Northport basement. When not between sheds, the boa's skin looks iridescent. Across the room is a tank with three larger boas wrapped around each other. Mr. Smith is more than happy to regale a rather skittish visitor by pulling out one of the eight-foot snakes and pointing out the bulge along its length that is most likely the rat it recently savored. Want to see another creepy crawler? From a vivarium in the next room, Mr. Smith proudly shows off an African millipede that freaks out his wife, Diane, every time he takes the coiled up brown critter out of the tank. ''It doesn't bite,'' said Mr. Smith, stroking the thousand-legged creature and touting it as an inexpensive pet that doesn't need walking and is content with a lump of lettuce and an occasional misting. ''It's a vegetable eater,'' he said. ''It has to feel a little bit comfortable and then it will start walking. It's interesting to see how the legs oscillate. The fear of every mom in America is that it gets out of the cage. That's why I have it here and not at my house.'' Mr. Smith's office is actually the headquarters of the Right Financial Group, which services computers and financial equipment in banks. But if his employees had any trepidation about working amid his extensive collection of reptiles, amphibians and insects in cages that make the rooms seem more like a pet shop, they have had to get over it. Since last January, when Mr. Smith launched Fauna magazine, the staff has been pulling double duty. Mr. Smith is an amateur herpetologist with big plans for this slick, full-color magazine stuffed with razor-sharp images of snake-necked turtles, legless lizards, giant hornets and the seldom seen ridge-nosed rattlesnake and articles with headlines like ''The Joy of Toads'' and ''Along Came a Spider.'' So far, he's been publishing 15,000 copies every other month, and toting his menagerie to schools all over the Island in search of an audience. His staff handles the business and advertising end; Mr. Smith does some editing but farms out assignments to scientists who know their invertebrates. The articles are geared to a general interest readers and are reviewed by an independent editorial board. ''When we do grow up, we'd like to be National Geographic,'' said Mr. Smith, 43. ''That's the benchmark for success in a nature magazine.'' Part of Mr. Smith's goal, he said, is to ''dispel the myth that snakes are evil monsters.'' ''On a survey, when people ask what are you most afraid of, even today, after Sept. 11, 50 percent of the respondents said snakes,'' he said. Tarantulas also rank up there on the scary charts, said Mr. Smith, reaching into another tank, plucking out an African scorpion while mimicking an eerie soundtrack with a shiver-inducing ''woooooooooooooo.'' ''This guy down here has a little danger involved,'' he said. ''There's a bit of a wives' tale in every James Bond movie. You see this thing is crawling on somebody and you think it is going to kill you like a tarantula,'' he said, knowledgeably noting that it's the claws that can clip a victim like a lobster and the stinger in the back is venomous, though not more than a yellow jacket sting. Mr. Smith said his hankering for creatures that others shirk away from propelled him to launch the magazine. ''I am a firm believer that these things have a right to exist,'' he said while readily admitting that though he's an environmentalist, the skin of a dead snake might make a fine-looking pair of shoes. ''There are enough people worrying about polar bears and jaguars. When you get into the wild and see the relationship between all these animals that live on the forest floor, that's why we started Fauna. It's the forgotten fauna. These are animals no one knows about or cares about anymore. They really are the basis of the food chain and the basis of life. Without them, everything stops. They are not in danger. They are just completely understudied and misunderstood.'' Mr. Smith's fascination with snakes started when he was 6. The family had just moved to West Babylon from Manhattan and he was having a hard time acclimating to the neighborhood. ''The kids across the hedges were screaming about something and out comes this little snake and I just instinctively went over and picked it up,'' he recalled. ''It just didn't dawn on me to do anything but.'' His soon-to-be best buddies were absolutely shocked. His mother ran out of the kitchen screaming ''put that down.'' The animal turned out to be a nonvenomous garter snake. From then on, he was hooked, venturing out on his bicycle all over the Island chasing down snakes, turtles and frogs, collecting them in a 55-gallon drum in the garage and peddling them to the pet departments of local department stores. Except for breaks during college, where he studied business economics, and when he got married, Mr. Smith kept up his hobby. When his oldest son, Tyler, now 12, caught a snake in the backyard as a toddler, Mr. Smith got the bug all over again and started breeding. For hibernation season coming up, Mr. Smith and his three children boxed their 50 to 60 reptiles into cozy sweater boxes and put them in the crawl space under the basement to sleep for the winter. Humans wiped out the rattlesnakes that were indigenous to Long Island more than 125 years ago, Mr. Smith said. He is looking farther. It was during a eco-tour of Costa Rica last year that he started talking about a business to promote reptiles and amphibians and the possibility of reincarnating Fauna was proposed. The name had been used on reptile magazines that came and went three times in the last 50 years. ''It means the animal kingdom, that's the true definition of the word,'' said Mr. Smith, hoping to someday make jungle tours of Costa Rica, Madagascar and the Amazon part of the magazine's outreach. ''We are just describing these forgotten species. We want people to understand that these animals certainly are not something you hit with a shovel if you see them in your garden, that they have a right to live.'' Literary Great Neck Great Neck has no shortage of literary aspirants. To celebrate the peninsula's writers, Muriel Turk, the director of programming for the Great Neck Library, initially compiled a list of people who grew up in Great Neck and became authors. ''We heard from very few of them but their parents called a lot,'' Ms. Turk said. However, she was inundated with calls from authors who had lived in town for decades and felt they should be remembered too. ''We are including writers of every ilk,'' Ms. Turk said, counting novelists, editors, critics, journalists, biographers, playwrights, essayists, songwriters and poets. The register topped 300. Among those who showed up at a dessert reception on a recent Sunday afternoon were Murray T. Bloom, who since he moved to the area 51 years ago, has written eight books, seven of them non-fiction. His novel, ''The Thirteenth Man,'' became a film, ''Last Embrace,'' with Roy Scheider; his 1969 book, ''The Trouble With Lawyers'' was a best seller. He said writers were attracted to Great Neck because of its proximity to the city and that the locals ''seemed to encourage literate pursuits.'' David J. Silverman, an enrolled agent and a Great Neck resident for three decades, was touting his ''Taxes for Dummies,'', now in its eighth edition. Robert H. Phillips, a psychologist, ticked off some of his more than 20 books on coping including, ''Overcoming Your Panic: A Strategy Guidebook,'' ''Coping with Diabetes'' and ''Coping with Breast Cancer.'' One-time author, Ricca Metz, was holding a copy of ''Maudie: A Positive Nursing Home Experience,'' a book about her mother published last year. Gordon Korman, who has written 40 children's books including ''No More Dead Dogs'' and ''I Want to Go Home,'' moved to Great Neck three years ago. He was thrilled to be recognized. ''That's one of the things about kids' books,'' Mr. Korman said. ''No one over the age of 14 knows who you are.'' Among literary luminaries on the list that will become part of the library's permanent collection were Herman Wouk, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Oscar Hammerstein and children's writers Margaret Wise Brown, Johanna Hurwitz and Esphyr Slobdkina. ''This is a library,'' Ms. Turk said. ''If there weren't authors and writers, what would we put on our shelves?''

docs.lead_paragraph: MORE than most other big ideas of the early Internet days, so-called community Web sites sounded like a true innovation, reflecting the medium's special capabilities. The premise -- build a site where people can freely chat or post messages or home pages, then get advertisers to pitch their goods to those people -- represented one of the lead horses of Wall Street's Internet stampede. Among the more obscure spinoffs of that trend were consumer feedback sites, which hoped to attract people who were so vehement about consumer issues that they would log on to let others know exactly how they felt about, say, the quality of Ford Explorers or customer service at Amazon. Word-of-mouth advertising would finally have a home, the thinking went, and that home was being promoted as a palace.

headline.main: E-Commerce Report; In the current Internet wilderness, some consumer community sites are hanging on, and even making money.

docs.lead_paragraph: Though shot in digital video and accompanied by a sprightly techno score, ''E-Dreams,'' Wonsuk Chin's documentary about the rise and fall of Kozmo.com has the artifactual feel of an old newsreel. The movie is a window into an era that feels curiously remote. Listening to the buoyant young C.E.O.'s and market analysts talk about their I.P.O.'s and market caps, you may feel a vague stirring of nostalgia, accompanied by mild disbelief. Did people really talk that way back then? Did they really believe that a business devoted to delivering videocassettes and pints of Ben and Jerry's to lazy urbanites could merit hundreds of millions of dollars in venture capital? Back then, of course, was around two years ago, in the giddy days of the dot-com boom. Residents of New York and a handful of other cities may remember Kozmo delivery folk with their orange bags zipping through intersections. Compulsive CNBC watchers will recognize Joseph Park, the affable, energetic 20-something who, along with his buddy Yong Kang, left jobs in investment banking to pursue what they, without irony or embarrassment, call their ''vision.'' Mr. Park was one of the Internet boom's media darlings, and in ''E-Dreams'' he spends a lot of time at photo shoots and in talk-show green rooms, and even more on his cellphone with journalists.

docs.lead_paragraph: Philip J. Kaplan's intended road to success is a familiar path from the dot-com boom: develop software code to solve a personal need, post it on a Web site and start generating income. Mr. Kaplan, of Manhattan, operates Amazonscan.com, a new Web site that grabs sales-ranking data from Amazon.com and displays the information as an enormous best-seller list of titles. Mr. Kaplan developed the program to track preorders for his own book, a look at failed Internet companies. The book, which will be published in April by Simon & Schuster, is based on his popular Web site that irreverently tracked the demise of failing dot-coms. (The site's name, in vulgar slang, translates as ''doomed company.'')

docs.lead_paragraph: After losing $2.8 billion since it was founded in 1995, the online retailer Amazon.com said yesterday that it had made its first quarterly profit, $5 million, validating at least in part its strategy to grow rapidly first and worry about profits later. Amazon's financial results were far better than expected because a yearlong efficiency drive sharply cut costs even as sales grew. An accounting gain related to the decline of the euro's value provided a final push. So the company was able to show a profit by the conventional standard, rather than merely by the nonstandard ''pro forma'' measures that it and other Internet companies prefer.

The order continued a pattern by the Bush administration of trying to distance itself from a corporate meltdown whose aftershocks have been felt in both the political and business worlds. [Page A1.]

docs.lead_paragraph: If you buy a motorcycle from Onelio Pimentel, you will be guest of honor at his monthly party in the town square. He will send you a card every year on your birthday. And he will always be waiting with a smile to show you the next new model. Mr. Pimentel, the 30-year-old business manager of the only Honda motorcycle dealer in this city of 72,000 on the banks of the Amazon, has good reason to grin. Despite an economic slowdown and an energy crisis that affected most of Brazilian industry, the number of motorcycles sold countrywide in 2001 jumped 20.5 percent, to 692,096. According to Abraciclo, the trade group for the two-wheeled sector, that makes it Brazil's highest-growth industry. Car sales grew around 9 percent in 2001, while overall industrial production is expected to have finished the year up only around 2 percent.

docs.lead_paragraph: PayPal has all the trappings of a classic dot-com bubble story. The company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., was conceived in 1998 by Peter Thiel, a smooth-talking hedge fund operator, and Max Levchin, a Russian-immigrant computer geek. It started out with the dubious business model of helping people ''beam'' money from one Palm Pilot to another. When the market for beamed money proved elusive, it switched to enabling people to e-mail each other cash. Mr. Thiel and Mr. Levchin, who declared that their little start-up would revolutionize commerce, persuaded venture capitalists to pour in more than $225 million. Unlike many such dot-com escapades, this little start-up has survived -- and thrived. PayPal has been enthusiastically adopted by the online community. In a single four-month period in 2000, registered users shot up from 10,000 to one million. The company now has over 13 million users, and annual revenues, generated by taking a small percentage of each transaction, of more than $100 million. PayPal isn't a sure thing. It's still not in the black, and it's had trouble with fraud. But it so dominates the fast-growing online payments business that Salomon Smith Barney is expected to take it public tomorrow in one of the most eagerly anticipated Internet I.P.O.'s in nearly two years.

Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 14. Now Playing ''A BEAUTIFUL MIND,'' starring Russell Crowe, Ed Harris and Jennifer Connelly. Directed by Ron Howard (PG-13, 129 minutes). In transforming the life of the brilliant mathematician John Forbes Nash Jr. into a muzzy, triumph-of-the-human-spirit Hollywood movie, Mr. Howard and his collaborators have stripped it of anything that might present the audience with the slightest discomfort or reason to think about the documented facts concerning Mr. Nash. On its own terms, though, the movie succeeds in dramatizing Mr. Nash's mental illness and to a lesser extent his mathematical insights. Mr. Crowe's performance is honest and focused, but the movie's conceptions of intellectual life and human character are ultimately so simplistic, so deeply mistrustful of the audience's intelligence, that any chance for genuine insight is squandered (A. O. Scott).

At I.B.M., her role is to oversee everything from the corporation's handling of employee data to devising systems to help protect privacy. In short, to be accountable at every level for the way I.B.M. manages its chief currency, information.

docs.lead_paragraph: The online booksellers Amazon.com and Barnesandnoble.com have settled a patent infringement lawsuit, ending a legal battle that began in 1999. In the suit, filed in October 1999, Amazon argued that the Barnesandnoble Web site used technology that was too similar to Amazon's patented One-Click system. Amazon's system stores billing and shipping information so online customers do not have to re-enter data each time they make a purchase.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE software industry has long been a staging ground for huge battles over intellectual property, starting perhaps 15 years ago when Apple Computer accused Microsoft of stealing the look and feel of the Macintosh. Today, the industry is awaiting an early-stage decision in the case of British Telcommunications v. Prodigy, another closely watched patent fight that, as have many before it, challenges a ubiquitous computing operation. At a preliminary hearing in a federal court in Westchester County, N.Y., last month, British Telecommunications, a subsidiary of the BT Group, asserted that it owned a patent on what is now known as hyperlinking, the process of linking Web pages so users can move from one page to another by simply clicking on highlighted text. Hyperlinking, a function about as basic to the Web as ramps are to a highway, is used by nearly every Web page, so that virtually no browsing can take place without it. According to British Telecom's arguments, without the technology that the company says is covered in its patent, now nearly 13 years old, computer users would have to know the address of a page before they could jump to it.

headline.main: New Economy; The Web world watches closely as British Telecommunications stakes a patent claim on a now-ubiquitous function: hyperlinking.

docs.lead_paragraph: MILLS-Alice duPont, of Middleburg, VA and Hobe Sound, FL, died March 13, 2002 at the age of 89, after a brief illness. Born in Wilmington, Delaware on December 13, 1912, Mrs. Mills was the daughter of the late A. Felix duPont and Mary Chichester duPont. After graduating from Oldfields, Mrs. Mills pursued a wide variety of interests. An advanced instrumentrated aircraft pilot, she flew an open-cockpit plane up the Amazon River in 1932 along with her late brother, Richard C. duPont. During World War II, she served as a flight instructor for military pilots in Long Island, N.Y., and upon the war's conclusion, piloted one of the pioneer single-engine airplane flights between New York and Buenos Aires with her husband, the late James Paul Mills, whom she married in 1935. Upon moving to Middleburg, Virginia in 1949, Mrs. Mills continued her involvement in philanthropic activities, environmental affairs and Thoroughbred horse racing. She pioneered numerous family planning programs in the course of her work for Planned Parenthood in Northern Virginia, and served as a member of Planned Parenthood's national board of directors, as well as local chairperson for its Mineola, NY chapter. Mrs. Mills was an active proponent of conservation efforts in Virginia, and in serving as founding member of the Piedmont Environmental Council and the Bull Run Conservancy, and later as Trustee of Virginia Outdoors Foundation, championed the preservation of scenic open spaces through conservation easement programs. As past chairperson and trustee of the Chichester duPont Foundation, Mrs. Mills promoted the efforts of numerous not-for-profit organizations throughout the nation. Her life-long passion for Thoroughbred horse racing and breeding was evidenced by numerous stakeswinners campaigned through her Hickory Tree Farm near Middleburg, including Believe It, Devils' Bag, Gone West, Gorytus, Glad Rags II and Hagley. Mrs. Mills was a member of Virginia Thoroughbred Association, and served as Trustee of the Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association. Her philanthropic efforts on behalf of Thoroughbred racing and Breeding included service as a founding member of the Marion duPont Scott Equine Medical Center, as Advisory Trustee to the National Museum of Racing, and as past Director of the Grayson-Jockey Club Research Foundation. Mrs. Mills was honored as 1991's Outstanding Owner/Breeder by the Virginia Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Assocation, and received the Kentucky Thoroughbred Breeders Association's Ladies' Sportsmanship Award in 1970. Mrs. Mills was predeceased by her husband, James Paul Mills, Sr., in 1987. She is survived by her daughters Mimi (Mrs. J. William) Abel Smith, of Middleburg, Virginia, and Phyllis (Mrs. James B.) Wyeth, of Chadds Ford, Pennsylvania; her son, James P. Mills, Jr., of Middleburg, and her grandchildren: Richard P. Mills, of New York and Sophie E. Mills of Rehoboth Beach, Delaware. A memorial Service will be held 4 PM, Saturday March 23, at the Grace Episcopal Church, the Plains, Virginia.

Directed by Kevin Bray (R, 99 minutes). In this fast, violent caper comedy, Ice Cube and Mr. Epps reprise the hip-hop-era, Martin-and-Lewis routing they inaugurated in ''Next Friday.'' There are some funny bits and a few stylish action sequences as the pair, playing a roughneck bounty hunter (Ice Cube) and a motormouth petty con man (Mr. Epps), chase after stolen diamonds, a winning lottery ticket and an international cast of bad guys. But the light comic tone is marred by gruesome, sadistic violence, and the rabid materialism suggested by the title (which refers to $100 bills) has an ugly, cynical edge (A. O. Scott).

''That's part of the reason why I'm here.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The recruiters gather at the bus station here in this grimy Amazon frontier town, waiting for the weary and the desperate to disembark. When they spot a target, they promise him a steady job, good pay, free housing and plenty of food. A quick handshake seals the deal. But for thousands of peasants, that handshake ensures a slide into slavery. No sooner do they board the battered trucks that take them to work felling trees and tending cattle deep in the jungle than they find themselves mired in debt, under armed guard and unable to leave their new workplace.

And then I logged on to Amazon.com to buy a book and was startled to see: ''Fred A. Bernstein, make $436.32. Sell your past purchases at Amazon.com today!'' In an audacious gambit to expand its marketplace, Amazon has not only become a broker of used books but has also found a way to prime the pump: encouraging people who bought books on Amazon to resell them.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gilman Louie is one of the most successful computer-game developers of all time. ''I'm your classic entrepreneur,'' he told me recently. ''I started my first business with my fraternity brothers at San Francisco State.'' Louie, an amateur fighter pilot, had his first big success in 1987 with a game called Falcon, which allowed players to simulate the flight of an F-16. Falcon sold millions of copies, not only to teenage boys but also to pilots in the United States Air Force, who found it so realistic that it helped them learn to fly real fighter jets. Louie's biggest success came in 1988, when he imported from the Soviet Union an unexpectedly addictive game called Tetris, which became the best-selling computer game ever. ''Between Nintendo sales and PC sales, 70 or 80 million copies of that game sold,'' Louie says. ''We even found out that Hillary Clinton loved playing Tetris on the Game Boy.'' Lots of companies were impressed by Louie's success, including Hasbro, which put him in charge of creating its games Web site. And then in 1998, Louie was recruited by an even more powerful employer: the Central Intelligence Agency. ''The C.I.A. actually thought that my computer-game background was a valuable asset,'' Louie recalls. ''I look at the world as one big system -- one big game.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week I got an e-mail message from the Authors Guild urging me to join its protest of Amazon.com's ''notorious used-book service.'' Amazon has lately been encouraging customers -- with offers on the same Web pages that promote new releases -- to resell recently purchased books and buy recycled ones. You'd think I would be up in arms. The other day Amazon was selling used copies of the hardcover edition of my book for $15 (list price is $26), and neither Simon & Schuster, my publisher, nor I will collect a nickel. That money will go to the reseller, minus Amazon's 99-cent fee and its 15 percent commission. Surely, as the guild claims, new book sales and royalties will suffer. Or will they? I drive a used car, live in a ''used'' house and own a lot of used economics books. As far as I know, purveyors of new cars, houses and textbooks are doing fine. Might Amazon's latest innovation be good for everyone, including authors?

docs.lead_paragraph: TEN heads nodded in unison around a long conference table as Rob Veres pointed to a large computer display. The scene was the latest of eBay's ''Voice of the Customer'' sessions, a brainchild of its chief executive, Meg Whitman. A cross-section of those who buy and sell over this huge online bazaar had been invited to eBay's headquarters here to spend two days talking to its executives. In one session, Mr. Veres, a product manager, showed proposed improvements to a feature called ''Mr. Lister,'' which lets users put dozens of items up for sale at the same time. There were murmurs of praise. Then Mr. Veres brought up an option that would let sellers specify that an auction would not start until a later date.

Rather, it's the opportunity to buzz through a series of books, knowing there will be no knocks at the door, no ringing telephone, and none of the 4,000 other obstacles that separate you from a good read. But for the book lover, plotting such a binge can be an exercise in angst. Do the reviews of the latest best-seller justify the three pounds and 64 cubic inches of space the book will eat up in your luggage? Are you really fit enough to add ''Anna Karenina'' to the other six books in the suitcase?

docs.lead_paragraph: Each time Rachel Ruskin, 11, enters a bookstore in her New York City neighborhood, she walks straight to the information desk to ask a question pressing on the minds of millions of children around the country: When will the next Harry Potter book appear? No one knows, not even J. K. Rowling, the British author who invented Harry Potter and the famous Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. After turning out four Harry Potter books at a rate of one a year through July 2000, Ms. Rowling is already months late in completing the fifth book in time for its planned publication in July. She has explained to her agent and publishers that writing this next book is proving to be more involved than she initially expected. Scholastic, the United States publisher for Ms. Rowling's previous books, has told its watchful shareholders only that the company expects to publish Ms. Rowling's next Harry Potter book some time before June 2003.

docs.lead_paragraph: Major debacles of historic dimensions -- and the collapse of Enron certainly qualifies -- tend to produce an excess of explanations. In Enron's case, some see the story as a failure of Enron's board, others blame the company's management, still others find fault with lax regulators or even inattentive shareholders. But the most important element in Enron's downfall, and the common denominator that links Enron and other recent financial scandals, is the performance of Enron's gatekeepers: auditors, securities analysts and others the market has long trusted to filter, verify and assess complicated financial information. None of these watchdogs detected Enron's problems until it was too late.

headline.main: Guarding the Gatekeepers

docs.lead_paragraph: Like many little-known authors, Janis Jaquith often wishes that some of the people buying best sellers would pick up her book instead. Now the online retailer Amazon.com is giving her a chance to express those feelings. docs.lead_paragraph: ''Secret Society,'' which opens today in New York, is the latest in an apparently endless series of British comedies in which an unlikely competitive activity becomes a way for hard-pressed ordinary folk to overcome adversity, gain self-esteem and find a moment of modest glory. To a roster that includes striptease (''The Full Monty''), hairdressing (''Blow Dry'') and gardening (''Greenfingers''), we may now add female sumo wrestling, the semi-clandestine pastime of a group of hefty Yorkshire cannery workers, among them Daisy, our heroine. Daisy (Charlotte Brittain), or Mistress Great White Jellyfish, as she comes to be known in the ring, lives with her adoring husband, Ken (Lee Ross), who dreams of striking it rich by selling naughty postcards of his zaftig bride. Impatient with this scheme, and a bit shy about exposing her body to the public, Daisy goes to work sorting carrots and peas. Before long, she notices that the large women in the factory, including Marlene (Annette Badland), the supervisor, seem to have a special bond, which turns out to be born of the ritual and discipline of sumo.

docs.lead_paragraph: 'The Internet has not only turned the used-book business inside out; it has flipped it on its head and spun it around once or twice,'' says Keith Waters, an instigator of one of the virtual era's more curious and less sung revolutions. Back in the mid-1990's, in the pre-dot-com dark ages, Waters was a computer consultant. One day, his wife, a used-book dealer, complained to him about how difficult it was to find any particular out-of-print book. Basically the only way to go about this was to scuffle through the local used-book stores or to pore through the 30 or so pages of AB Bookman, a weekly magazine that published lists of titles. Waters examined AB Bookman and had his flash of inspiration: why not create an Internet equivalent, a searchable database that would connect thousands of dealers, instead of only a few, and list millions of books, instead of thousands? And so in 1996 he founded Advanced Book Exchange, www.abebooks.com. Abebooks now links some 10,000 used- and rare-book dealers worldwide, each paying a monthly subscription according to how many titles they put online. Abebooks currently lists more than 38 million books, with 50,000 to 100,000 added every day. If you want to search for a newer book, Robert A. Caro's ''Master of the Senate,'' say, or an old paperback of Ray Bradbury's ''Fahrenheit 451,'' you simply go to the Web site, type in the author's name and title and scores of choices pop up. You take your pick, depending on price and condition. In this fashion, the market itself makes the price for a given book, and no book, in or out of print, is hard to find anymore.

The bad news is that the S.E.C. concluded that Amazon did help one of those companies falsify its books. The result yesterday was that Amazon.com accepted a cease-and-desist order from the S.E.C., ordering it not to help anyone else violate securities laws. As penalties go for violating securities laws, it was one of the lesser ones, but it was a violation nonetheless.

docs.lead_paragraph: Since its inception, Amazon.com has helped with dinner, with cookbooks, then cookware. Now it has a new service: menus from thousands of restaurants in New York, Boston, Chicago, San Francisco, Seattle and Washington are on the Web site. The menus are cross-referenced by neighborhood, cuisine or even a particular dish. Prices, addresses, telephone numbers are given, and driving directions can be obtained. There is no charge to the consumer or the restaurant. Carrie Peters, a spokeswoman for Amazon, stressed that the service was an experiment. Indeed, the listings have not been fine-tuned: some menus are not given, some are outdated and some restaurants have closed. The restaurants whose menus appear were not consulted. ''I don't know how it happened but I don't think it can hurt,'' said Danny Meyer, an owner of Union Square Cafe and Gramercy Tavern, two New York restaurants that are featured. Ms. Peters said restaurants could have their menus removed if they wished. The site (click on ''Restaurants'' under the Service heading of Amazon.com) also has a list of the most popular restaurants in each city, based Zagat-style on consumer response.

docs.lead_paragraph: Zandra Rhodes is an exotic -- a rare species. She looks like a cross between Glinda the Good Witch and something you would find in an Easter basket. She has bright pink hair, an insane amount of blue eye shadow, two different colors of lipstick -- one for the top and one for the bottom -- and she sleeps in her makeup because ''to put it on every day would simply take too much time.'' With her chipped nail polish and Cockney accent, she's a psychedelic Mary Poppins. Zandra's designs reinterpret primitive cultures on printed chiffon -- Native American, Mayan, Chinese -- creating her own civilization of Amazon debutantes on their way to the ball. Her dresses are unmistakably Zandra -- hand-crafted, ethereal, raw-edged and impossible to copy. ''Zandra is one of the great textile designers,'' says Susannah Frankel, a fashion writer for the London-based Independent and a Zandra devotee. ''The clothes come from the textiles, which is a very unusual way of working, and makes for something that is very special and limited edition,'' she explains. ''She's grouped with Ossie Clark as purveyor of true hippie chic -- but couture, much more than ripped jeans.''

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush is expected to approve the resumption of a program to force down or shoot down airplanes suspected of ferrying drugs in Latin America, a year after the program was halted by the mistaken downing of a plane carrying American missionaries in Peru, American officials say. American officials said air interdiction operations could begin in Colombia as early as this fall and would likely be expanded to Peru later. The Pentagon would support the program as well, providing intelligence about suspected drug flights gathered from ground-based radars and from other sources, officials said.

docs.lead_paragraph: MALCOLM STOGO, wearing a crisp white dress shirt and khaki pants, walked across his pristine kitchen here in Riverdale, pulling a small commercial ice cream maker he had retrieved from his pantry. He was going to make a batch of homemade piña colada ice cream for a client in Korea. Mr. Stogo has developed and marketed some of the world's richest ice creams for manufacturers all over the world. ''I want it to taste like a piña colada drink,'' Mr. Stogo, 61, said in a no-nonsense Philadelphia accent. A $20-billion-a-year business that absorbs nearly 9 percent of all the milk produced in the United States, ice cream today is at the center of an industry that pivots on the ability of taste-makers like Mr. Stogo to dream up and deliver irresistible flavors.

docs.lead_paragraph: High and dry on the pavement of the Newport Shipyard in Rhode Island, the 118-foot icebreaking schooner Seamaster bears scant resemblance to the immaculate, gleaming pleasure yachts lining the nearby slips. With its unfinished aluminum hull, massive double rig and general workmanlike appearance, in more ways than one it's a ship out of water. Among the neighboring boats with their polished metal fittings and varnished brightwork, Seamaster looks like a vessel straight from the movie ''Waterworld.'' The first mate, the New Zealand sailor Errol Olphert -- better known as Ollie -- disagrees.

docs.lead_paragraph: The St. Louis Zoo has just opened a 10-acre exhibit called River's Edge, recreating habitats from South America, Africa, Asia and the zoo's home state of Missouri. In the Amazon backwater, visitors can see bush dogs, web-footed cousins of the wolf; giant anteaters; and capybaras, the world's largest rodents, weighing about 100 pounds. The African reserve features black rhinos that weigh more than a ton; Nile hippos; cheetahs; spotted hyenas; and dwarf mongooses, the smallest African carnivores, which feed on rodents and insects. The Missouri wetlands area includes local river fish like gar, bluegill and catfish, as well as softshell, map and slider turtles.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com posted slightly better-than-expected financial results yesterday, as its operations continued to stabilize. Amazon, the largest online retailer, lost $94 million in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $168 million a year earlier. The company, whose sales stagnated last year, increased revenue by 21 percent, to $806 million, a little more than expected. It attributed the increase to its price-cutting strategy -- discounting books that cost more than $15 and offering free shipping on orders of at least $49.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''This is my Rosetta stone,'' Dr. Alexander E. Gates was saying as he stood before a vast chunk of rock near Lake Tiorati in Harriman State Park. A video crew was capturing his every syllable. ''A single rock outcrop can reveal the entire geologic history of this park,'' he said. ''And this one shows evidence of a continental collision where two of the earth's plates hit together, and then later, hot magma intruded at 1,000 degrees centigrade.'' He gestured toward the gray wall.

docs.lead_paragraph: For as long as Brazil has been a nation, outlaws of every type, from gold smugglers and slave traders to drug traffickers and gun runners, have taken refuge in the Amazon, the world's largest jungle wilderness, secure in the knowledge that they could not be tracked down. As of today, though, that shelter is no longer guaranteed. A new American-financed, $1.4 billion system of radars and sensors has begun monitoring activity in a 1.9-million-square-mile area of trackless rain forest and rivers that is larger than half the continental United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: HOW'S this for a disaster in the making? A writer and artist, living and working out of a third-floor walkup, decide to start their own publishing house. They have limited funds and almost no experience in the book business. To make matters even worse, the first two volumes they plan to issue seem to have almost no commercial potential. ''What makes us particularly lunatic is that we're starting off with a book of poetry and a book of literary criticism,'' said Dennis Loy Johnson, who, with his partner, Valerie Merians, is the driving force behind Melville House Publishing, which will release its first offerings in September. ''Two big sellers. Absolute sure fire hits.''

docs.lead_paragraph: ''It's not about the books,'' he says. ''My fans are buying the DNA of Dave.'' Dave Pelzer is sitting in the lobby of the Hilton in Daytona Beach, Fla., watching college girls in bikinis run by. He's a vaguely good-looking man, vaguely nerdy, with a squinting, almost spinsterish smile. ''I was shy with girls,'' he says. ''At 21, I had this girl in my room. I poured her a glass of wine, turned around, and she was taking her shirt off. I said, 'I guess it's all right to kiss you.''' Pelzer, 41, the author of three autobiographical books and one self-help book, is on his spring speaking and book-signing tour. Daytona is one of the bigger cities on his route; most of his stops are in smaller towns. After a speech in the morning in Daytona Beach, then a book signing later that day, he will leave at 1 a.m., drive two hours to Orlando Airport, catch a 6 a.m. flight to Butte, Mont., and then fly to North Platte, Neb.

docs.lead_paragraph: High technology, with Microsoft at the helm, has put Seattle on the map. Still, lumber and agriculture formed the city's industrial backbone, and the old economy continues to play an important role in the Puget Sound area. The retailers Nordstrom and Costco are here, as are the insurance giant Safeco (which has acquired naming rights to the home of the Seattle Mariners, Safeco Field) and, of course, Starbucks and its ubiquitous coffee houses. The wobbly American economy has not spared Seattle. The jobless rate, which hovered around 3.3 percent in the late 1990's, has doubled since then, and the once robust housing market has weakened. Boeing's decision to move its world headquarters to Chicago last year cost the area 13,800 jobs, to say nothing of a measure of Seattle's pride. On the other hand, Amazon recently reported quarterly results that were slightly better than expected.

docs.lead_paragraph: General Electric, the nation's biggest company by stock market value, yesterday joined a small but growing group of companies that are changing how they account for stock options. G.E. went even further by saying that top executives would no longer be allowed to take profits immediately after cashing in options. Responding to criticism that options-heavy pay packages have given executives enormous incentives to create short-term profits, G.E. said it would require its top officers to hold, for at least a year, some of the shares they get after exercising options. It also said those officers would have to hold substantial stock positions as long as they work at the company.

docs.lead_paragraph: OVER his 25-year career, the director Hector Babenco has shown an affinity for film adaptations of prestigious but difficult books. His 1985 version of Manuel Puig's ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' won William Hurt an Academy Award for best actor, and he was also called upon to translate William Kennedy's ''Ironweed'' and Peter Matthiessen's ''At Play in the Fields of the Lord'' into film. But Mr. Babenco comes to ''Carandiru,'' his latest project, with attachments that are surely novel in the annals of moviemaking. If it weren't for his prodding, the prize-winning Brazilian best seller on which the film is based would probably not have been written. On the other hand, it is thanks to Dr. Dráuzio Varella, the book's author, that Mr. Babenco is still alive to make the movie.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last month, Brazil inaugurated a high-tech radar system to keep watch on its two million square miles of Amazon jungle. The American-financed $1.4 billion Amazon Vigilance System will help catch drug smugglers and detect incursions by Colombia's guerrillas. But it was originally conceived and designed for environmental protection, and can still be a key tool in combating deforestation and illegal mining. The system, however, is only as good as Brazil's willingness to use the information it provides -- and there the record is worrisome. An average of more than 7,500 square miles of the Amazon go up in smoke every year as ranchers and farmers clear land. The deforestation destroys biodiversity and, by robbing the landscape of its ability to retain water, contributes to drought and erosion.

A shootout near the Damascus Gate in Jerusalem's Old City left three people dead; two ambushes wounded seven Israelis; and a fifth attack in the West Bank killed a married couple. The Islamic group Hamas claimed responsibility for the bus bombing. A1 U.S. Grants Uruguay a Loan The Bush administration said it would grant up to $1.5 billion in short-term loans to Uruguay, an infusion that should allow its banks to reopen this morning. The loan, announced after emergency legislation was passed in Uruguay to help quell the nation's economic crisis, would be the first of its sort by the Bush administration to assist another country directly in a financial crisis. docs.lead_paragraph: THE ART OF TRAVEL By Alain de Botton 255 pages. Pantheon Books. $23. With his quirky 1997 book ''How Proust Can Change Your Life,'' Alain de Botton hit upon a formula for talking about art and highbrow concerns in a deliberately lowbrow way: the book playfully proposed to read Proust's great masterwork ''Remembrance of Things Past'' as a self-help book, as a guide to better living. Mr. de Botton's book, which blithely mixed biography and philosophy with literary criticism and Seinfeldian asides, possessed a certain genial charm that sprang from his decidedly tongue-in-cheek tone.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Target Corporation and Amazon.com deepened what was already a close online relationship yesterday when they announced that Target's three store chains -- Mervyn's, Marshall Field's and Target -- were now using Amazon's online retail services. Mervyn's and Marshall Field's online customers are redirected to the Target.com site. Once there, customers may buy merchandise from each of the stores within the Target chain and may also purchase books, music and videos from Amazon. While Target continues to handle shipping and warehousing for Mervyn's and Marshall Field's online orders, Amazon operates the site on behalf of all the stores, using technology similar to that offered on Amazon.com. Amazon executes all shipping and handling for products from the Target brand store. The specific terms of the deal, which was initially announced in September and is now going into effect, were not disclosed, but Amazon will earn sales commissions and a flat annual fee. Amazon has had a Target store within the Amazon.com Web site since October. Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: Not far from Washington is a voluptuously landscaped public park called Brookside Gardens, 50 acres of tumbling giant feather grass, creeping St. John's wort, Brazilian verbena, rose mallows, hibiscus trees, Madagascar periwinkles, crape myrtle, purple plum trees, lemon-scented gum trees, Amazon water lilies and welcoming lotuses. Butterflies as big as fists and hummingbirds the size of thumbs dart through the controlled extravagance, but food is forbidden in the gardens, so you won't be pestered by platoons of ants, flies or yellow jackets, and there is scant standing water in which nature's wretched little phlebotomists can breed.

docs.lead_paragraph: By decree, the official burning season here in the Amazon is supposed to be severely limited in scope and not to start until Sept. 15. Yet the skies south of here are already thick with smoke as big landowners set the jungle ablaze to clear the way for cattle pasture and lucrative crops like soybeans. The Amazon basin, which is larger than all of Europe and extends over nine countries, accounts for more than half of what remains of the world's tropical forests. But in spite of heightened efforts in recent years to limit deforestation and encourage ''sustainable development,'' the assault on its resources continues, with Brazil in the lead.

headline.main: Amazon Forest Still Burning Despite the Good Intentions

docs.lead_paragraph: Life is good at the bottom of the cyberspace pit. When the Arizona attorney general's office recently shut down a Scottsdale company, CP Direct, it offered a glimpse into the spoils of the Internet's dark side. The company sold pills via the Web that promised to increase penis length, bust size and body height. Enough people had spent $60 an order -- mostly for the ''Longitude'' treatments, with ingredients that included pumpkin seed, sarsaparilla and ''oyster meat'' -- that the state was able to seize more than $30 million in luxury real estate and a herd of Mercedes-Benzes, Rolls Royces and a Lamborghini.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon.com yesterday cut by half the amount shoppers must spend to have merchandise shipped free as the company, the world's largest Internet retailer, seeks to lift sales and gain new customers. Shoppers who buy $25 or more of certain products can get free shipping under a test program, Amazon.com said in a statement. In June, Amazon reduced the minimum purchase required for free shipping to $49 from $99. The lowering of shipping costs is an attempt to turn browsers into buyers and persuade existing customers to order more, the company said. Amazon also expanded discounts in April, offering a 30 percent price reduction on any book with a publisher's list price of more than $15. It previously offered the discount on books of more than $20. ''It's probably a sign that they're having a good quarter,'' said Darren Chervitz, research director for Jacob Asset Management in New York. Customers who select free shipping must accept delivery schedules as much as five days longer than Amazon.com's regular services. Shares of Amazon fell 24 cents, to $14.93.

docs.lead_paragraph: Roosters are on my mind. After all, Hilly Kaplan and I have been up all night talking with ''El Gallo,'' -- the Rooster, if you will -- certainly one of the most fascinating men I've ever met, and not just because of the Cuban rum we have been nipping on till four in the morning. El Gallo is a Bolivian hydraulic engineer, and Hilly and I have been sitting for five hours on the porch of his mother's small hotel in San Borja, Bolivia, a frontier town of 12,000 people in the Bolivian Amazon. We have been talking Bolivian and world politics, rural development, anthropology and health care. El Gallo is well versed in almost all those topics, quietly charismatic in multiple languages, but best of all, he is a great storyteller.

In one sign of that change, peasants are again being encouraged to cultivate rubber and Brazil nut trees, the twin pillars of the economy here before major deforestation began in the 1970's.

docs.lead_paragraph: AMY SACCO, the owner of the superhip Chelsea clubs Lot 61 and Bungalow 8, stands 6-foot-1 in her stocking feet (and 6-foot-4 in her Dolce & Gabbana stilettos). She is a husky-voiced Amazon in perpetual search of sleep. She tumbles into bed about 4 in the morning to the sound of trucks rumbling down her street. ''If I could, I'd encapsulate myself in complete darkness and silence,'' she said. Last year, Ms. Sacco went with a friend to visit Giuseppe Lignano and Ada Tolla, the partners in LOT-EK, the Manhattan architecture firm known for working with offbeat industrial materials. There, she flipped open a book on their work and saw the bed of her dreams. It is a sleep pod made from an oil tank, with sides that close to shut out sound and light.

docs.lead_paragraph: Call it what you will: kitsch, pornography, artifact, feminist propaganda or a major work of 20th-century art. It doesn't make much difference. ''The Dinner Party,'' the extravagant ceramic and textile homage to women through history that Judy Chicago dreamed up and translated into reality in the 1970's, is important. It is almost as much a part of American culture as Norman Rockwell, Walt Disney, W.P.A. murals and the AIDS quilt, and it is similarly subject to debate. It has been denounced from the floor of Congress and alternately attacked and defended by critics of all persuasions, feminist and otherwise. As with most works of such prominence, its historical import and social significance may be greater than its aesthetic value, but the three are so intricately and distinctly enmeshed that an altogether different kind of weight results. Furthermore, the great if idiosyncratic collection of the Brooklyn Museum of Art is the perfect place for a work like this.

docs.lead_paragraph: After the environmental leader Chico Mendes was killed near here late in 1988, the movement he personified went into shock and was expected by many simply to fade away. It recovered, and his allies, heirs and disciples now govern this remote Amazon region. Nearly four years ago, one of Mr. Mendes's closest associates, Jorge Viana, was elected governor of Acre State and embarked on an ambitious experiment that has gained growing support here and abroad. Rather than simply raze the jungle, as his predecessors had always done, he promised instead a ''government for the forest'' and the people who live there.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1911, in a London lecture hall, Prof. George Challenger produces a map he claims shows the way to a mysterious ''lost world'' somewhere in the uncharted depths of the Amazon jungle. His requests for participants and financial backing are met with heckling from his more conventional colleagues - until Lord John Roxton, a renowned biggame hunter, signs up for the expedition. Soon, Prof. Leo Summerlee, Challenger's archrival, and Edward Malone, a young reporter, are clamoring to join in the adventure. Little do they know that far beyond the smog and gaslights, exists a forgotten land - populated by terrifying ancient creatures - from which they may never return.

docs.lead_paragraph: Big Bertha pantaloons, sensual Eastern robes, corsair pirate coats over lacy skirts -- Balzac's ghost must have been howling as a gust of 19th-century Romanticism whipped through the spring 2003 collections. Mention ''romance'' in fashion, and automatically your mind reels back to Cartier-Bresson's images of wartime lovers locked in neck-breaking kisses. But if you want to click with modern audiences, if you want to fill them with a sense of wanderlust in an age gone stale with brands and shop openings, then you have to go back further -- to the mid-19th century, when much of the world still lay unexplored and romantics were tricked out in exotic splendor.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE anthropologist Claude Lévi-Strauss once wondered ruefully whether ''pictures could offer something substantial to readers who have never been there.'' The Brazilian photographer Valdir Cruz believes they can. Over the last six years he has traveled the Amazon, photographing people who live in some of the remotest regions of the rain forest, especially the so-called Fierce People, the Yanomami, of northern Brazil and Venezuela. Captured in his current exhibition, at Throckmorton in Manhattan, and a comprehensive book of his photographs, ''Faces of the Rainforest,'' by Mr. Cruz, Kenneth R. Good and Vicki Goldberg (PowerHouse), the ''something substantial'' he has brought back is art. In the process, he has become an aid worker and a political activist, found himself a partner in controversy and discovered someone thought to be dead. And his adventures didn't end when he returned to civilization. ''I didn't become interested in photographing in the rain forest until long after I had left Brazil,'' Mr. Cruz said recently in his neat apartment in the West Village. ''I grew up in a small town in the south, and like many places in Brazil, we never thought much about the Indians. To this day, in Brasilia and São Paulo, people aren't interested in these pictures.'' Mr. Cruz came to the United States in the late 1970's and learned photography with George Tice at the New School in Manhattan. ''All I really cared about was making beautiful images,'' he said.

docs.lead_paragraph: I. Wall Street Didn't Do It A few weeks ago, on ''Moneyline,'' a guest who didn't fully understand just how much times have changed invoked some corporation's ability to beat Wall Street's forecasts for its quarterly earnings. Before you could say ''market manipulation,'' the program's host, Lou Dobbs, said, ''Do you really think anybody's paying attention to that silly expectation stuff anymore?'' He dismissed forecasts as ''the game of the late 90's.'' And he had a point. For many years, Wall Street analysts have low-balled their earnings estimates so that their corporate customers could announce to the press that they had ''beaten'' those estimates. This particular game was exposed beginning in the late 1990's by fledgling Web sites, which routinely published more accurate earnings forecasts than the Wall Street pros. By the middle of 1998 the stock market began to trade off the Web estimates rather than the Street estimates -- which tells you how fully understood this quarterly forecast game had become even before the boom reached its turn-of-the-century heights. But so long as the stock market rose, Lou Dobbs was happy to listen to Wall Street and corporate big shots blather on about how they had beaten their earnings forecasts. He didn't scorn them; like every other serious reporter, he treated them as useful informants (when he wasn't distracted by his bid to make his Internet fortune in a doomed start-up called Space.com). And yet now, somehow, Lou Dobbs, like every other serious reporter, knows enough to raise his eyebrows and harshen his tone when anyone mentions earnings estimates. As wide-eyed as he was three years ago, he is narrow-eyed now. You can't put one over Lou Dobbs!

headline.main: In Defense of the Boom

docs.abstract: Michael Lewis article says rush to punish corporate wrongdoers is rewriting history, obscuring what was great about 90's; says it was during boom that rational, egalitarian structure--in which workers, through stock and options, had stake in their enterprise--gained popular acceptance; says periods of great prosperity always wind up being periods of great scandal; suggests scandal may somehow be essential ingredient in capitalism; says healthy free-market economy must tempt certain number of people to behave corruptly; says corporate crooks should be rounded up, but it is worth asking how they got away with it in the first place; questions where bold regulators and fire-breathing journalists were five years ago, when it actually would have been brave to inveigh against excesses of boom; says very people now baying so loudly for blood were in most cases creating climate that rewarded corrupt proctices; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Environmentalists in this cloud forest of northern Ecuador still dream of halting construction of a new oil pipeline that the builders said could bring spectacular wealth to this poor Andean country. But with the 300-mile-long, privately financed pipeline now 70 percent complete, and long green tubes replacing the palm and canelo trees, even the most die-hard opponents acknowledge that stopping the construction is next to impossible. The announcement this month that the big Düsseldorf bank Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, or WestLB, would continue financing the project, despite an international campaign pressuring it to withdraw a $900 million loan, appeared to remove the last hurdle for the builders of the $1.3 billion pipeline.

docs.lead_paragraph: Conservation biology has long been driven by a mission to save all the pieces at whatever cost. But just as questions about accounting are shaking up the financial world, conservationists are beginning to pay much closer attention to results. They are looking for more bang for the buck -- not just financially but biologically, too. In recent months, scientists from diverse conservation groups have been meeting to discuss principles and accounting standards for auditing environmental projects. Two of the largest conservation groups, the Nature Conservancy and the World Wildlife Fund, are leading the effort, with help from the nonprofit Foundations of Success, which specializes in measuring results.

headline.main: Fiscal Accountability Concerns Come to Conservation

docs.lead_paragraph: The Loudeye Corporation, a company based in Seattle that develops Webcasting technology, announced an agreement with Amazon.com yesterday to provide music samples on Amazon's popular retail site. Loudeye replaces Muze, which had previously provided music samples for Amazon. Loudeye says that it now provides music samples for a majority of online retail music sites and that last year it served more than 620 million samples. The company has deals with all five major recording companies and offers music samples from over 250,000 CD's. Last week, the company reported revenue of $3.6 million for the third quarter, a 45 percent increase over the period last year. It also trimmed its net loss to $4.1 million, compared with a $12 million loss in the quarter a year earlier. Shares in the company jumped on news of the Amazon.com agreement, gaining 12 cents, to 49 cents. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: If there's such a thing as the perfect DVD movie, it has to be ''The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring.'' On Tuesday New Line is to release two four-disc special editions only three months after issuing a basic two-disc DVD in August. This time Peter Jackson's film has been lengthened by 30 minutes in a ''platinum edition'' ($39.99) loaded with 30 hours of features and a ''collector's DVD gift set'' with even more extras and upgraded packaging ($79.92). Of course, distributors never object to selling a film over again in expanded forms, and given the zealousness of J. R. R. Tolkien fans and an ocean of behind-the-scenes material, few films lend themselves better than ''The Fellowship.'' Also, prospects of the first ''Rings'' sequel, ''The Two Towers,'' opening in theaters next month, attract those looking to gear up.

docs.lead_paragraph: Segway L.L.C., makers of a much-promoted electric-powered scooter that has captured the imagination of many technophiles, said yesterday that consumers could begin ordering the pricey vehicles on Amazon.com. Two years after rumors of its existence set the high-tech world abuzz, the Segway Human Transporter has gone on sale for $4,950 on Amazon.com, the companies said. Deliveries start in March, first come first served. The Human Transporter is a self-balancing two-wheeled vehicle that looks like an old-fashioned push-type lawnmower updated for the 21st century. Kept upright by a series of computer controlled gyroscopes, the device is compact enough to be driven on sidewalks. Segway believes it has enough manufacturing capacity to meet demand because the company relies on standard industry components from suppliers like Michelin and Delphi. However, the only promise now on shipments is that delivery will be made by August. The move puts consumers closer to stepping on the electric-powered scooters, but a variety of hurdles remain to gaining mainstream acceptance, including the vehicle's hefty price tag and a tangle of state legal restrictions.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I appreciated the perceptive review of my book ''Breaking Open the Head: A Psychedelic Journey Into the Heart of Contemporary Shamanism'' (Nov. 10), yet I felt compelled to offer one important factual correction. The reviewer states that DMT (dimethyltryptamine) is ''a powerful synthetic drug.'' While it is powerful, it is not in fact synthetic. DMT has been found in the human brain and spinal cord, and seems to be secreted by the pineal gland. It is also produced by many plants throughout the Amazon and elsewhere. The smokable form of DMT may be synthesized or refined from plants, but DMT itself is a naturally occurring compound. Daniel Pinchbeck New York

docs.lead_paragraph: At least five people died and dozens were missing after a boat crammed with up to 300 passengers capsized and sank on a river in the Amazon jungle, officials said. The riverboat, the Dom Luiz 15-1, licensed to carry 140 passengers but with additional cargo capacity, sank Tuesday night near Barcarena, about 2,000 miles north of Rio. A spokeswoman for the Para State river service said that 207 people had been rescued and that 50 to 80 people were missing.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two new programs at the National Aquarium in Baltimore offer a look behind the scenes for small guided groups. Participants in the two-and-a-half-hour Gallery Tour enter the aquarium before it opens, have breakfast and visit the most popular exhibits: the Amazon River Forest, Open Ocean, Atlantic Coral Reef and a temporary exhibit on seahorses. The tour offers a peek at how the aquarium prepares the food for its animals and the feeding of the residents of the Atlantic Coral Reef. It is offered Saturday and Sunday at 9:15 a.m. and costs $40; $37 age 60 and older, and $34 age 5 to 11. Children under 5 are not permitted. Dolphin Discovery tours start with a visit to the marine mammal kitchen. Participants investigate the mechanics of providing the aquarium with air and water and join a trainer to meet the dolphins up close. This tour, on Saturday at 2:30 p.m., lasts two and a half hours, and costs $58; $54 for those 60 and older; $49 age 8 to 11. Children under 8 are not permitted.

docs.lead_paragraph: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva will not become president of Brazil until Jan. 1. But even before he and his cabinet have a chance to start their promised overhaul of Latin America's largest country, some of his key appointees are fending off charges of conflict of interest or confronting opposition from within the president-elect's own fractious coalition. Elected on a left-wing platform, Mr. da Silva has surprised and disappointed many of his more ardent followers in the Workers' Party by turning to pillars of the business establishment to fill the principal economic policy-making slots in his government. But those advisers come with considerable baggage, including judicial inquiries, tax problems and large debts owed to agencies they will soon be supervising.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE year 2002 will surely go down as one of the worst in business history. Scandal rocked corporate suites and Washington offices, jobs evaporated, the American economy muddled along and Europe and Latin America reeled. Rogues at companies like WorldCom and Enron were bad enough, but even superstar executives like Jack Welch contributed to the staining of corporate America.

headline.main: Coming Up Roses In a Downcast Year

docs.abstract: Profiles of dozen people who scored major business successes in 2002, bucking trend in disastrous year; they are David Neeleman of JetBlue Airways, Clive Calder and Clive Davis of BMG, Lawrence F Probst III of Electronic Arts, John Mackey of Whole Foods Market, Sallie L Crawcheck of Citigroup, Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer of New York, Michael S Dell of Dell Computer, Carleton S Fiorina of Hewlett-Packard, James F Rothenberg of Capital Research and Management, Jeff Bewkes of AOL Time Warner, Barry Diller of USA Interactive and Jeff Bezos of Amazon.com; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: The best comedy is a science, a rigorously structured subversion of logic. Absurdist humor lost its greatest illogician this year, though most Americans didn't notice. Spike Milligan, who died of kidney failure in February at 83, wrote and performed ''The Goon Show,'' a BBC radio program that was broadcast from 1951 to 1960. It generally had a cast numbering only three -- Milligan, Peter Sellers and Harry Secombe -- but the trio played dozens of roles, ranging from witless vagrants to witless ministers of Parliament. The Goons' influence has long outlived its radio years. Troupes like Beyond the Fringe and Monty Python, by their own admission, were the Goons' clear descendants; some would even argue that their work was derivative of Milligan's anarchic style. ''The Goon Show'' never caught fire on this side of the Atlantic. With its fast pace, difficult accents and very English in-jokes, it sounded like a foreign language to American audiences. In the States, radio has long been regarded as a crippled form of TV, but Milligan brilliantly exploited every virtue of the form. That you could not see the action was the entire point. In one episode, Milligan, playing his central role of a toothless idiot named Eccles, inexplicably falls in love with one of Peter Sellers's characters. ''My little darling, I want you to have these,'' Milligan drawls, arriving at Sellers's door. ''I picked these for you. I grew them myself.'' Sellers tries to be gracious. ''A handful of hair!'' he responds. ''How sweet. Butler! Put these in a jar of hair oil.''

headline.main: Insanely Funny

docs.abstract: Marshall Sella pays tribute to British comedian Spike Milligan, whose absurdist comedy influenced Monty Python and others; Milligan died in 2002; photo (M)
